div1.head: Newspaper clipping, New York Sun, August 24th, [1907?]
div1.p:
Governor MAGOON'S criticism of the
Cuban officials is of course justified by
their delinquencies. It is a fact beyond
the reach of controversy that they sol-
emnly assumed a certain responsibility
in connection with sanitary work in the
island and that no proper effort has been
made by them to discharge their obliga-
tions. The Governor might have gone
much further in reproach without passing
the bounds of reason.

It is to be considered, however, that
the Cubans can hardly be expected to
take the same view of yellow fever and
the mosquito theory that we do. The
disease does not create for them the
superstitious terrors it inspires in our
minds. In their philosophy it is a fa-
miliar if not an inevitable concomitant
of life. They do not regard it as espe-
cially dangerous, nor are they ready to
believe that the mosquito, even if it be
the sole cause of yellow fever, as alleged,
is susceptible of complete extermina-
tion. Besides, they doubtless recall the
time, not so very remote, when our au-
thorities gravely announced that yellow
fever had been permanently “stamped
out,” not by killing the mosquitoes but
by sweeping the streets, cleaning all
private premises, in fact, through a
rigid dispensation of the broom, the
dustpan and the scrubbing brush.

That was the Ludlow-Wood hypothe-
sis, proclaimed in 1900, and in its day it
was as stoutly and confidently main-
tained as was the stegomyia theory that
came along a year or so later. We are
not suggesting an excuse for the Cuban
officials. They have neglected both the
filth piles and the insects, have kept no
promises of any kind and have slept on
every duty.

The fact remains, nevertheless, that
these people are not like us and cannot
be made so, no matter how diligently we
may strive. If we did not know this
when we abandoned the island to them
it was our fault, not theirs. Only a very
credulous or unobservant person could
have imagined that they would depart
from the customs of centuries in order
to eradicate a disease which they do not
fear and to destroy an insect which prob-
ably does not cause them the slightest
inconvenience.
